history.content:
To answer each of your questions:

1) Yes. I have taken a Math 1B equivalent in community college and it easily transferred over. As far as 4 year institutions go, I know that UC Berkeley allows inter UC course credits. Not too sure about other 4 year institutions, but seeing as CoE accepts community college credit, I don't see why they wouldn't accept a course from another 4 year institution.

2) You will have satisfied that requirement. Is the intention of this question in relation to prerequisites? Then yes. If you take an equivalent Math 54 course at a community college, then you will have satisfied the Math 54 prerequisite that some upper divs may have.

3) The most important take away from this entire post: You CANNOT take lower divs at a community college during the school year. It is ONLY permitted during the summer. (My EECS adviser emphasized this).

children.subject:
Thanks for the thorough response!

For 2) though, I was referring specifically to *online* classes. Would I still get credit for classes taken online vs in person? Or does it not matter, as long as it's listed on ASSIST?

history.content: The above poster is correct. There is no list of courses from four year schools; these must be evaluated individually. Please see your adviser with questions.

Does the College of Engineering (specifically, EECS) give credit for lower-div classes (like Chem 1A/L, or Physics 7C,  or Math 54) taken online through other institutions (community college or 4-year colleges)? If so, is there a list of institutions that COE will accept online course credits from? I've been looking at ASSIST, but that's only for community colleges.

Furthermore, if a community college offers an online course, and that course is listed as acceptable on ASSIST, we will be able to get Berkeley credits for that course, correct?

Also, if I do decide to take some lower-divs at a community college, will I only be able to do so during the summer? Or could I only do so during the school year?
history.subject: Credit for online lower-div courses
